awd_titl_txt: An Examination of Social Support Figures as Prepared Safety Stimuli
awd_abstract_narration:
It is crucial that people develop the ability to identify and respond to threats as they navigate the world. Yet, the process by which people learn about threatening cues is inexact, often producing excessive fears, disruptive fear responses, and anxiety. Based on the importance that close social ties have for survival, this research examines social support figures as stimuli that promote survival.  Such 'prepared safety stimuli' promote feelings of safety and may reduce threat responses.  This is in contrast to 'prepared fear stimuli' that have historically threatened human survival (e.g., snakes, spiders). Considerable research has focused on prepared fear stimuli, but little prior work has examined prepared safety stimuli. This research will develop an understanding of these unique safety signals and the beneficial role they might play in both preventing people from learning new fears and aiding people in extinguishing old ones. This research will also help to develop a deeper understanding of the role of social support figures as prepared safety stimuli. In addition, this research may illuminate avenues for improving current interventions targeted at reducing maladaptive fears and anxiety, thereby improving well-being.

	The proposed research will bridge the social support and fear learning literatures, employing a combination of fear conditioning, social buffering, and neuroimaging methods. In a series of studies, Dr. Naomi Eisenberger at the University of California, Los Angeles, will define prepared safety stimuli and test whether social support figures fulfill those parameters. The proposed studies will further the examination of social support figures as prepared safety stimuli by examining: 1) whether social support figures, but not other familiar or rewarding stimuli (which are not turned to for social support), serve as prepared safety stimuli, 2) whether ambivalent support figures, who are sources of both positivity (support) and negativity (stress/negative affect), can serve as prepared safety stimuli, 3) whether stimuli historically associated with the presence of social support (warmth, softness) act as prepared safety stimuli, 4) the neural regions that underlie the safety effects of social support figures, and 5) whether support figures inhibit fear learning and enhance fear extinction to other stimuli. Given the prevalence of anxiety and fear-related disorders in the United States, understanding the unique functions of prepared safety stimuli and the role they might play in preventing fear learning or extinguishing learned fears has the potential to pave the way for new interventions targeted at reducing maladaptive fear and anxiety.

por.por_cntn:
Based on findings showing that social support figures are powerful, natural inhibitors of fear during Pavlovian fear learning processes, the goal of this work was to conduct the first-ever investigations of the role of social support figures during fear learning. These investigations have revealed that while social support figures naturally, without specific training, pass the tests of the most powerful learned safety signals (conditioned inhibitors), familiar others and rewarding stimuli do not (Hornstein, Fanselow, & Eisenberger, 2016), indicating that it is the social support value of social support figures, not their familiar or rewarding properties, that enable them to be prepared safety stimuli. This work has also revealed that another survival-relevant stimulus that has been associated with social support throughout evolutionary history, physical warmth, performs the same functions as social support figures and naturally passes the tests of conditioned inhibitors (Hornstein, Fanselow, & Eisenberger, 2022), expanding the category of known prepared safety stimuli. Additionally, this work has demonstrated that social support figure stimuli are able to alter fear learning outcomes by influencing how fear is learned to other cues. Specifically, when social support figures are present, the acquisition of new fears is reduced (Hornstein & Eisenberger, 2017) and the extinction of already held fears is enhanced (Hornstein, Haltom, Shirole, & Eisenberger, 2018)?effects that are in contrast to other known fear inhibitors, such as learned safety signals. Finally, this work has revealed that these effects may be occurring due to social-support-specific activity in inhibitory pathways in the brain?in particular, social-support-driven increases in activity in the ventromedial prefrontal cortex (a neural region associated with safety processing) and corresponding, decreased activity in the amygdala (a neural region associated with fear responding and learning) (Hornstein, Leschak, Haltom, Parrish, & Eisenberger, revise & resubmit). 

            These results represent an important step forward in scientific understanding, revealing that social support figures appear to belong to a before-unknown category of fear inhibitors that are able to both inhibit fear in the short-term, while present (as known fear inhibitors do) as well as reduce fear learning in the long-term, after being removed (which is in contrast to known inhibitors). This unique combination of effects has been posited to place social support figures, and physically warm stimuli, in an altogether new category of inhibitor?prepared fear suppressors (Hornstein, Craske, Fanselow, & Eisenberger, 2021)?that, due to their survival relevance, are enabled with the ability to simultaneously inhibit fear and reduce fear learning. Understanding of this category both contributes to the ever-evolving understanding of Pavlovian learning and how different factors influence learning outcomes as well as to the growing understanding of the important role played by social bonds in how we learn to be afraid.

            In addition to contributing to scientific understanding, these results provide important insight into methods to reduce fears in the long-term, insight that is especially critical given current assessments that 1 in 3 adults in the US will experience a fear disorder over the course of their lifetime, including anxiety disorders, PTSD, and phobias. The most effective method to date to reduce the dysfunctional fears that are a hallmark of such disorders?exposure therapies?relies on Pavlovian extinction processes to produce new learning that mitigates fear responding. Thus, knowledge of the extinction-enhancing effects of social support figures offers a potential pathway to boost exposure therapies and improve treatment outcomes. Furthermore, the acquisition-reducing abilities of social support figures may represent a method to prevent the development of dysfunctional fears in those most at risk, such as individuals with anxiety disorders who are prone to excessive fears or individuals in highly threatening environments (i.e., soldiers in a warzone) who have a higher risk of trauma. 

Altogether, the outcomes of this project represent the crucial first step forward in understanding the unique role of social support figures during the fear learning process as well as how this knowledge can contribute to boosting interventions targeted at reducing fear and improving outcomes in those with fear disorders.
